author: imikushin
title: Oneiron: Cardano Sidechain SDK
description: To build a Cardano sidechain, a LOT of developer effort is needed. Most developers are not familiar with Plutus or even Haskell, but have experience with JVM-based languages or JavaScript.

f6_assessments.q0:
Yes, this proposal effectively addresses the challenge by creating a Cardano side chain that is focused on bringing in JVM-JS developers into the ecosystem.

The proposer does a good job at outlining the problem of Plutus being relatively unfamiliar to developers, which may deter many existing developers from launching their products on Cardano. By developing the JVM side chain, these developers would not need to go through the painstaking work of learning Plutus but instead can continue working and delivering in their language of choice, including: Java, Kotlin, Scala, Clojure, etc., as well as JavaScript, Python, Ruby. 

I appreciate that the proposer also listed the exact components of the challenge brief which they align with. By laying it out so clearly it is easy for voters and assessors to see that it is in the right challenge. If successful it certainly would result in more cross chain collaboration by reducing the learning curve to participate in Cardano.
f6_assessments.q1:
Yes, given the experience and plan presented it is very likely that this proposal will be implemented successfully. 

What I like about this proposal is that it's straight forward and simple to follow but has clear deliverables and timelines. The proposer essentially wants to build a proof of concept sidechain using JVM. They do a good job at keeping the scope narrow enough to be achievable. While some of the measures may be a little idealistic "Potentially thousands of sidechains created with the SDK, inevitably leading to activity growth", the exact project itself is not expected to achieve this. Rather, getting a working side chain able to interact with the main chain is the goal. To this end, the timelines and deliverables listed appear very feasible given the proposer's experience. 

Another good point about this proposal is that there are examples of already working side chains that the proposer could look to for guidance/advice. I would have liked to know if the proposer has already reached out to these groups and whether they seemed keen to support this project. If they see it as a threat/competition to their already ongoing work, they may not be willing to help, and in so doing, may impact the feasibility. 

What I do think could be better described is the budget. How did you get to the hourly rate of $256. First off, it's a bit random of an amount and there is no indication that this is market rate or whether it's based on other projects the proposer has worked on. I think for that request there should be at least some explanation as to what comparators you are using.
f6_assessments.q2:
Yes, the information provided is sufficient to audit the progress and success of the proposal. 

Any project that is open-source by default (like this one) should give additional confidence to voters that there will be opportunities for auditing. By using github, community members can interact with the proposer and their code, which can reduce the amount of time bugs or glitches go unnoticed, and thereby improve the overall performance of the side chain. 

As mentioned above, the fact that this plan is quite straightforward, the proposer has identified several achievable success measures, such as: being able to download the sidechain with CLI, sending ADA from the main chain to the side chain, and using JS to write a smart contract for the side chain. These clear goals make it easy for the community to know whether it achieved what it set out to. 

I look forward to the outcome of this project.

f6_assessments.q0:
Challenge problem is clear:
To build on Cardano, or to build a sidechain to Cardano, a developer needs a firm understanding of Plutus or Haskell and a lot of developers do not have this skill set/education making it difficult for projects to develop on Cardano or its sidechains. This proposal brings a solution to this issue on the side of sidechains. The proposal is setting out to develop a JVM-based Cardano Sidechain SDK (Oneiron: Cardano Sidechain SDK). There are a lot of people who are well versed in JVM-based or JavaScript based coding in the world. This would enable an untold number of developers to be able to work and develop on the Cardano side chain.

This proposal is found in the Cross-Chain Collaboration challenge
This proposal lines up beautifully with the metrics of this challenge.
- Oneiron opens up the Cardano ecosystem to hordes of enterprise/web developers.
- Oneiron is open source
- Easy creation of Cardano sidechains with the Oneiron SDK and the JVM-based language runtime will bridge the skill gap for existing enterprise/web developers.
- Potentially thousands of sidechains created with the SDK, inevitably leading to activity growth.
- Building cross-chain bridges will be far easier with the sidechain SDK.
The impact that this proposal brings to Cardano ecosystem is immense and only time can accurately describe just how potent the impact will be as already existing developers would now be able to develop on the Cardano blockchain.

This proposal effectively addresses the challenge
f6_assessments.q1:
The timeline/plan set forth in this proposal is achievable, well laid out step by step to accomplish their goals as well as resources the proposer will be using. The team has taken the time to consider risks that they may have, and how to go about mitigating those risks. 

As far as the team itself we are given one individual Ivan Mikushin who is the proposer of this proposal. However, the proposer has listed his skill and experience, and has also provided a link to linked in where we can see his developer endorsements, amazing skills, extraordinary experience and the like. Based on this information, I would say he is well qualified to do the tasks outlined in the timeline/plan. 

Looking at the budget side of this proposal the proposer has laid it out based on an average hourly wage, multiplied by the number of weeks needed to complete the work of this proposal, and has concluded that 65536 will be sufficient, and based on everything in the timeline plus a little contingency to be sure, I agree that this is sufficient.

The proposer has also let us know that he will return for further funding, and that this funding is to get the project up and running. He has listed the things he will be needing future funding for. The proposer has clearly thought this through completely. 

Given experience and plan presented it is highly likely this proposal will be implemented successfully
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposer has let us know what metrics he will use to measure progress and success of this project. Furthermore he lets us know that he will measure development velocity in number of points in delivered features every 2 weeks (we will produce a release every 2 weeks). (NOTE: Any any new proposal please let us know where or how you will produce these releases. It is important for the community to be able to view these releases to keep up with the success and progress of the project once funded.) These metrics are sufficient in monitoring/auditing the progress of this project, though it would have been nice to see a timeline or time horizons and what is expected in those timeframes. Even though we can conclude this from the feasibility section, it is best that proposer lay this out clearly.

The information provided is sufficient to audit the progress and the success of the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal has the potential to have a lot of impact on Cardano itself. But It´s not entirely aligned to the Cross-Chain collaboration challenge, since it is not emphasizing the cross-collaboration aspect. Hence I cannot give a score higher than 4 in this department.

This proposal would be better suited for the "The great migration" challenge.

I´d also suggest the proposer use less technical language to have more success in the voting stage.
f6_assessments.q1:
Even though the proposer is working alone on this project, I believe the experience (with proof) and timelines make the proposal very feasible.
The details are given on the plan and the detailed recognizance of the challenges shows the proposer has a very concrete scheme of how he will tackle the challenges. Given all the above aspects, I give the proposal 5 stars in the Feasibility department.
f6_assessments.q2:
On the positive side, the proposer gives a detailed breakdown of the budget he's going to need and provides a system of audibility to ensure he's working on the project.

But, the proposer does not give enough detail about how this "points" system is going to work. And, realistically, it would take a highly technically capable individual to audit this proposal. Hence why I cannot rate this aspect with a score higher than 4 stars.

I'd advise the proposer to provide further information about how his proposal is going to be audited. Possibly making a system for a non-technical individual to be able to audit it.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal intends to build an open-source JVM-based Cardano Sidechain SDK titled Oneiron SDK to bring the Cardano ecosystem to millions of enterprise software developers, who are now not familiar with Plutus or even Haskell but have certain experience with JVM-based languages or JavaScript. Serving this purpose, the proposal is well aligned with the challenge. Thanks to its well-written and clearly-presented description, the project is quite easy to understand. The proposer provides 5 key metrics to measure the impact of the projects, which, I think, are well chosen and aligned with those required by the challenge for evaluating its success. Once completed, the project potentially helps thousands of side chains created with the SDK, inevitably leading to activity growth of the Cardano system. As for the possible risk that the team might face, the proposal not only points it out but also offers some practical steps to mitigate it. My rating is 5.
f6_assessments.q1: As for the timeline of the project, the proposal presents a time-framed timeline that spans over up to 7 months at most with the desired outcome after each milestone. The founding engineer is the only one working on this project. The proposal offers a pretty detailed description of him and provides his LinkedIn and Twitter profiles for reference. The budget breakdown part might look short and simple but I think it’s all that we need for this one-member project. It covers the salary for the proposer during the course of implementing the project. My rating is 5.
f6_assessments.q2: Speaking of the project auditability, the proposer plans to estimate all deliverable feature development work in “points” and measure development velocity in the number of points in delivered features every 2 weeks. I find this an effective and easy way for the community to audit the project. Furthermore, the proposal clearly outlines the success criteria of the project, which consists of 3 components. The second one could have been a little more specific. The proposer expects to see “some amount of ADA” to be transferred from the main Cardano blockchain into the sidechain and back. This criterion will become more specific if the proposer presents a detailed number of ADB to be transferred. Overall, this part is pretty well written, well organized and well understood. My rating is also 5.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal is very harmonious with this challenge, as it suggests the creation of a Cardano Sidechain SDK (Oneiron SDK) that will allow many developers to build a sidechain from programming languages ​​with which they are already more familiar (Haskell and mainly Plutus are languages ​​in which few professionals have knowledge). I think this initiative will open doors, because Cardano is really a third generation blockchain and the languages ​​we work with – mainly Plutus – are very new, so much so that the official program for learning Plutus is called plutus PIONEERS. Once there is some bridge between the languages ​​most known by professionals and Cardano, most likely the adoption of our network will increase, which will generate new cross-network projects, for example, which are the main objective of this challenge. For these reasons, I believe that the proposal is very accurate, and despite being technical, it is accessible to read, at least for PAs/vPAs/voters who have been part of our community for some time.
f6_assessments.q1: The script is very simple and clear, but it does not lack in terms of placing us in relation to what would happen in the project development process. As we can see in the excerpt “M4 (2-4 weeks): The SDK can be installed using Homebrew (brew install) on macOS. Support for other package managers is on the backlog”, a short summary of what would happen each week is given; splitting the timeline into weeks is a great way for us to understand exactly what would be done and when. The hourly rate charged is very expensive: “With the hourly rate of $256, the total project cost is $256/h × 8 h/w × 32 w = $65,536”. From my knowledge as a PA since f5, the average asking amount for developer work is $100, less than half that amount. It is up to the voters to decide whether this value is fair, but in my view it is well above average. A lot of confidence is conveyed about Ivan, who would run the project. He has two decades of experience and attaches his linkedin profile so that we can see more in practice what is said about him.
f6_assessments.q2: I suggest that the bidder, in addition to the suggested measurements ("We will also measure codebase unit test coverage (keep it high) and build time (keep it low)"), do some monitoring work. your routine. It could be a monthly report, where it would give us information about what was done that month, if there were challenges, how they were mitigated, etc. The ultimate success is well defined (“An enterprise or web application developer can install the Oneiron SDK and create a single-node Cardano sidechain in 15 minutes by following the instructions in the README project on GitHub”, etc); however the proponent should have suggested some way to keep in touch with our community and demonstrate the real impacts of the project. A great way to do that would be, for example, if he told us some practical examples of developers who would be making use of the technology, and also some cross-network projects that grew out of here.

solution: A JVM-based Cardano Sidechain SDK will close this gap and open Cardano ecosystem to millions of enterprise software developers. Thousands public and private Cardano sidechains will be created.
experience: Experience leading teams, building software with a spectrum of technologies: imperative and functional languages (mostly, JVM-based), web stacks, Kubernetes. Plutus Pioneer (3rd cohort).
